description: From Middle English double, from Old French doble, double, from Latin duplus (“twofold”). Doublet of doppio and duple.

entries.meaning: Made up of two matching or complementary elements.
examples: The closet has double doors.

entries.meaning: Of twice the quantity.
examples: Give me a double serving of mashed potatoes.

entries.meaning: Of a family relationship, related on both the maternal and paternal sides of a family.
examples: He's my double cousin as my mother's sister married my father's brother.

entries.meaning: Designed for two users.
examples: a double room

entries.meaning: Folded in two; composed of two layers.
Stooping; bent over.
Having two aspects; ambiguous.
examples: a double meaning

entries.meaning: False, deceitful, or hypocritical.
examples: a double life

entries.meaning: Of flowers, having more than the normal number of petals.
(music) Of an instrument, sounding an octave lower.
examples: a double bass

entries.meaning: (music) Of time, twice as fast.
Twice over; twofold; doubly.
examples: I was double their age.

entries.meaning: Two together; two at a time. (especially in see double)
examples: There are only a few beds, so some of the children will have to sleep double for the night.

entries.meaning: Twice the number, amount, size, etc.
A person who resembles and stands in for another person, often for safety purposes
examples: Saddam Hussein was rumored to have many doubles.

entries.meaning: A drink with two portions of alcohol.
examples: On second thought, make that a double.

entries.meaning: A ghostly apparition of a living person; a doppelgänger.
A sharp turn, especially a return on one's own tracks.
A redundant item for which an identical item already exists.
examples: I have more than 200 stamps in my collection but they're not all unique: some are doubles.
Before printing the photos, Liam deleted the doubles.

entries.meaning: (baseball) A two-base hit.
examples: The catcher hit a double to lead off the ninth.

entries.meaning: (bridge) A call that increases certain scoring points if the last preceding bid becomes the contract.
(billiards) A strike in which the object ball is struck so as to make it rebound against the cushion to an opposite pocket.
A bet on two horses in different races in which any winnings from the first race are placed on the horse in the later race.
examples: Not only did I collect on the double; I had the win and the place money as well.

entries.meaning: (darts) The narrow outermost ring on a dartboard.
(darts) A hit on this ring.
(dominoes) A tile that has the same value (i.e., the same number of pips) on both sides.
(computing, programming) A double-precision floating-point number.
examples: The sine function returns a double.

entries.meaning: (soccer) Two competitions, usually one league and one cup, won by the same team in a single season.
(rowing) A boat for two scullers.
(sports) The feat of scoring twice in one game.
(sports, chiefly swimming and track) The feat of winning two events in a single meet or competition.
examples: In 1996, Michael Johnson achieved a double by winning both the 200 and 400 meter dashes.

entries.meaning: (historical) A former French coin worth one-sixth of a sou.
(historical, Guernsey) A copper coin worth one-eighth of a penny.
examples: As for doubles, they are not worth anything now; and I have still got an egg-cupful my mother used to keep handy to give the baker change from a farthing.

entries.meaning: (music) Playing the same part on two instruments, alternately.
(Christianity) A double feast.
Synonym of double-quick (“fast marching pace”)

verbs.description: double (third-person singular simple present doubles, present participle doubling, simple past and past participle doubled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To multiply by two.
examples: The company doubled their earnings per share over last quarter.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To increase by 100%, to become twice as large in size.
examples: Our earnings have doubled in the last year.

entries.meaning: To be the double of; to exceed by twofold; to contain or be worth twice as much as.
(transitive) To fold over so as to make two folds.
examples: To make a pleat, double the material at the waist.

entries.meaning: (transitive) (sometimes followed by up) To clench (a fist).
(baseball) To get a two-base hit.
examples: The batter doubled into the corner.

entries.meaning: (transitive) (often followed by together or up) To join or couple.
(transitive) To repeat exactly; copy.
(transitive with as) To serve a second role or have a second purpose.
examples: A spork is a kind of fork that doubles as a spoon.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, sometimes with "for") To act as substitute for (another theatrical performer in a certain role, etc).
examples: Laforêt, who (as the French express it), doubles Lainez, that is, performs the same characters in his absence.

entries.meaning: (theater) To play (both one part and another, in the same play, etc).
examples: When, therefore, Briggs, the sedate, middle-aged individual, who in the Markham household doubles the roles of butler and valet, makes his  appearance, his master affects to be in a great hurry, looks at his watch, and says :  […]

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To turn sharply, following a winding course.
(nautical) To sail around (a headland or other point).
examples: Sailing along the coast, he doubled the promontory of Carthage.

entries.meaning: (music) To duplicate (a part) either in unison or at the octave above or below it.
(music, intransitive, usually followed by "on") To be capable of performing (upon an additional instrument).
(bridge) To make a call that will double certain scoring points if the preceding bid becomes the contract.
(card games, intransitive) To double down.
(billiards, snooker, pool) To cause (a ball) to rebound from a cushion before entering the pocket.
(intransitive) To go or march at twice the normal speed.
(transitive) To multiply the strength or effect of by two.
examples: Sorry, this store does not double coupons.

entries.meaning: (military) To unite, as ranks or files, so as to form one from each two.
(radio, informal, of a station) To transmit simultaneously on the same channel as another station, either unintentionally or deliberately, causing interference.
examples: Could you please repeat your last transmission? Another station was doubling with you.

entries.meaning: (espionage, intransitive) To operate as a double agent.
examples: Was this simply the cover name of an Allied spy-code named the Brass Monkey?  […]  The possibility that the Brass Monkey himself was "doubling" (with headquarters' approval, of course) is too logical  […]
